Unconsolidated Shore (Lake/River/Pond)
bWODUx-w2.memHandModelNotes: Hartke and Hepp (2004), stated that natural cavities used by breeding wood ducks were located <0.5 km from the nearest wetland or shoreline, with most nest within <0.16 Km.  Ryan et al. (1998), found 82% of their study nest in upland woodland environments were located >1 Km from permenant water.  However, in this study paratization rates were high in the floodplain nest location, which could account for the expanded use of upland nest locations. They also elucidated two additional studies in Missouri and Minnesota where there were similar results.  Wood ducks generally use shallow waters or waters edge. Anderson et al. (1981), Nests in low slow moving waters of <18 inches deep. ******Do not restrict wet vegetation with and INTO buffer (i.e. all wetland habitats). Amy Silvano 01Sept05

references.A91LIV01NAUS: Livezey, B. C. 1991. A phylogenetic analysis and classification of recent dabbling ducks (tribe Anatini) based on comparative morphology. Auk 108:471-507.
references.B95HEP01SEGP: Hepp, G.R. and F.C. Bellrose. 1995. Wood duck (Aix sponsa). In A. Poole and F. Gill, eds., The Birds of North America, No. 169. The Academy of Natural Sciences, Philadelphia and The American Ornithologists' Union, Washington, DC.
references.A87LAC01NAUS: Lacki, M. J., S. P. George, and P. J. Viscosi. 1987. Evaluation of site variables affecting nest box use by wood ducks. Wildl. Soc. Bull. 15:196-200.
references.A98RYA01SEGP: Ryan, D. C., R. J. Kawula,and D R. J. Gates. 1998. Breeding biology of Wood Ducks using natural cavities in southern Illinois. J. Wild]. Manage. 62:112-123.
references.A99YET01USGP: Yetter, Aaron P., Stephen P. Havera, and Christopher S. Hine. 1999. Natural-Cavity use by nesting Wood ducks in Illinois. The Journal of Wildlife Mgt. Vol. 63, No. 2, 630-638.
references.B92AND01NAUS: Andrews, R., and R. Righter. 1992. Colorado birds:a reference to their distribution and habitat. Denver Museum Natural History xxxviii + 442 pp.
references.B92DUG01NAUS: Dugger, K. M., and L. H. Fredrickson. 1992. Life history and habitat needs of the wood duck. U.S. Fish Wildl. Serv., Fish and Wildlife Leaflet 13(1.6). 8 pp.
references.B88ROO01NAUS: Root, T. 1988. Atlas of wintering North American birds:An analysis of Christmas Bird Count data. University of Chicago Press. 336 pp.
references.B97NIC01NCGP: Nicholson CP. 1997. Atlas of the breeding birds of Tennessee. Knoxville: University of Tennessee Press.
references.B94BEL01NAUS: Bellrose, F. C., and D. J. Holm, editors. 1994. Ecology and management of the wood duck. Stackpole Books, Mechanicsburg, Pennsylvania. 588 pp.
references.B73HES01NAUS: Hester, F. E., and J. Dermid. 1973. The world of the wood duck. J. B. Lippencott Co., Philidelphia. 160 pp.
references.B86RID01NAUS: Ridlehuber, K. T., and J. W. Teaford. 1986. Wood duck nest boxes. Section 5.1.2, US Army Corps of Engineers Wildlife Resources Management Manual. Tech. Rep. EL-86-12. Waterways Expt. Station, Vicksburg, Mississippi. 21 pp.
references.B80POT01NAUS: Potter, E. F., J. F. Parnell, and R. P. Teulings. 1980. Birds of the Carolinas. Univ. North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill. 408 pp.
references.W09NAT01USGP: NatureServe. 2009. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer. (Accessed: March, 2010 ).
references.B90DRO01NAUS: Droege, S., and J.R. Sauer. 1990. North American Breeding Bird Survey, annual summary, 1989. U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Biological Report 90(8). 22 pp.
references.A04HAR01SEGP: Hartke, K.M., and G.R. Hepp. 2004. Habitat use and preferences of breeding female wood ducks. Journal of Wildlife Management 68(1). Pp 84-93
references.N90FUS01NCGP: Fussell, J. III and M. Lyons. 1990. Birds of the Outer Banks [pamphlet]. Eastern National Parks and Monument Association Coastal Wildlife Refuge Society.
references.B76PAL02NAUS: Palmer, R. S., editor. 1976. Handbook of North American birds. Vol. 3. Waterfowl (concluded). Eiders, wood ducks, diving ducks, mergansers, stifftails. Yale Univ. Press, New Haven. 560 pp.
references.B94FUS01NCGP: Fussell, J.O. III. 1994. A birder's guide to coastal North Carolina. Chapel Hill and London: The University of North Carolina Press.
references.B83AOU01USGP: American Ornithologists' Union (AOU). 1983. Check-list of North American Birds, 6th edition. Allen Press, Inc., Lawrence, Kansas. 877 pp.
references.B76FWS01NAUS: U.S. Fish & Wildl. Serv. 1976. Nest boxes for wood ducks. U.S. Fish & Wildl. Serv. Wildl., Wildl. Leaflet 510. 14 pp.
references.B67KOR01NAUS: Kortright, F.H. 1967. The ducks, geese, and swans of North America. The Stackpole Company, Harrisburg, PA, and Wildlife Management Institute, Washington, D.C. 476 pp.
references.B88FWS01NAUS: U.S. Fish & Wildl. Serv. 1988. SEIS 88. Final supplemental environmental impact statement:issuance of annual regulations permitting the sport hunting of migratory birds. x + 340 pp.
references.A91HEP01NAUS: Hepp, G. R., and J. E. Hines. 1991. Factors affecting winter distribution and migration distance of wood ducks from southern breeding populations. Condor 93:884-891.
references.A88SEM03NAUS: Semel, B., P. W. Sherman, and S. M. Byers. 1988. Effects of brood parasitism and nest-box placement on wood duck breeding ecology. Condor 90:920-930.
references.B59PEA01NCGP: Pearson, T.G. 1959. Birds of North Carolina. Raleigh, NC: Bynum Printing Company.
references.A85HAR01USGP: Haramis, G. M. and D. Q. Thompson. 1985. Density-production characteristics of box-nesting Wood Ducks in a northern greentree impoundment. J. Wildl. Manage. 49:429-436.
references.B80TER01NAUS: Terres, J.K. 1980. The Audubon Society encyclopedia of North American birds. Alfred A. Knopf, New York.
references.R81AND04SEGP: Anderson, S.H., C.S. Robbins, and J.R. Partelow. 1981. Habitat Management for Birds of Alabama. Technical Report Number FWS/OBS-81/39.3, Eastern Energy and Land Use Team, US Fish and Wildlife Service, Laurel, MD

habitat_description:
All Regions:
Wide variety of habitats: creeks, rivers, overflow, bottomlands, swamps, marshes, beaver and farm ponds. Although swamps, marsh, and overflow areas may provide better habitat than streams, the extensive distribution of streams creates the single most important habitat for breeding birds (Bellrose and Holm 1994). Current data suggest that structure and use of habitats are similar among seasons, but more quantitative information is needed on seasonal habitat use (Fredrickson and Graber 1990). Freshwater wetlands with an abundance of vegetative cover are important habitats in all seasons. Because of steep topography in the West, narrow riparian zones along waterways are important there (Bartonek et al. 1990)(quoted directly from Hepp and Bellrose 1995).

Northwest:
GENERAL (Nature Serve):  Herbaceous wetland, lagoon, river mouth/tidal river (Estuarine), big river, creek, low gradient, medium river (riverine), shallow water (lacustrine), bog/fen, forested wetland, riparian (palustrine), Conifer, mixed, and hardwood forests and woodlands (Terrestrial).
Habitat includes quiet inland waters near woodland, at areas such as wooded swamps, flooded forest, greentree reservoirs, ponds, marshes and along streams. Utilize large holes in large trees in forested wetlands, and in bird boxes within 0.5 km of water and near forest canopy.  Nests in tree cavities with at least 9 cm entrance, an interior basal area of at least 258 sq cm at a height of 2 meter or more above the ground. Elms and maples are important habitat components in most areas where they commonly provide protein-rich samaras in spring and suitable nest cavities. Often returns to the same nesting area and same nest box in successive years (moving to a new nest site after nest is destroyed).  Female may lead young up to several km to suitable habitat (food and cover). Important cover for broods includes shallowly flooded habitat with understory.  Commonly lays eggs in conspecifics’ nest (Nature Serve).

Southwest:
Summer resident and transient in western Nevada; winter resident in southern Nevada (Alcorn 1988). Colorado: common resident in Grand Valley, Mesa Co., and on eastern plains, breeding locally. Very rare at all seasons in western valleys oustide of Grand Valley (Andrews and Righter,1992). Habitat: reservoirs, lakes, rivers shaded by tall overhead vegetation. Narrow riparian zones along waterways in the West are important for this region (Hepp and Bellrose 1995). Freshwater wetlands with abundant vegetative cover important habitat all year round. Interspersion of flooded shrubs, water tolerant trees, small areas of open water resulting in 50-70% cover are favored. Beaver ponds are good habitat.  In areas where traditional habitats are lacking, birds use agricultural land and open areas. The birds are usually associated with flooded woodlands rather than open marshes. New Mexico: migrate and winter (New Mexico Department of Game and Fish, 2000). This species occurs year round in Utah although it is more common in state during the winter (Utah Division of Wildlife Resources, 2003). Wood ducks prefer marshes and ponds near woodlands and are especially fond of flooded fields.

Southeast:
Wood ducks will utilize a wide variety of freshwater habitats such as creeks, rivers, bottomlands, swamps, marshes, beaver and farm ponds (Hepp & Bellrose 1995). They generally prefer slow-moving waters surrounded by deciduous or mixed woods, especially where large willows, cottonwoods, and oaks are present (Anderson et al. 1981, Hepp & Bellrose 1995).
Nests in cavities in live or dead trees located in, near, or a distance from water (Potter et al. 1980). Trees are often older and larger than the typical second-growth. Frequently uses cavities made by Pileated Woodpeckers (Haramis 1990). Cavities are located 2-65 feet above ground, with those at least 30 feet above ground being preferrred. Depth of preferred cavities has been found to average 10-19 inches (Bellrose et al. 1964). Will also nest in chimneys or nest boxes (Potter et al. 1980). Upon arrival in breeding areas, migratory females forage intensively and built up nutrient reserves prior to nesting. Nests are initiated as early as late January in the south, early March in the Midwest, and mid-March to early April in the north. Clutch size is 9-15 (usually 10-12), but more than one female may contribute eggs to a nest, resulting in nests with many more eggs (commonly up to 30 for successful nests in nest boxes). Often two broods per year are raised in the south, occasionally in the north. Incubation lasts 27-37 days, by female. Females with broods commonly move a kilometer or more from the nest site soon after hatching. Most juvenile mortality occurs during the first few weeks after hatching. Young first fly at about 9 weeks, abandoned by parent at 1-2 months. Yearlings may breed but often unsuccessfully or not at all. Most of the above information is from Dugger and Fredrickson 1992).
Hartke and Hepp (2004), stated that natural cavities used by breeding wood ducks were located <0.5 km from the nearest wetland or shoreline, with most nest within <0.16 Km.  Ryan et al. (1998), found 82% of their study nest in upland woodland environments were located >1 Km from permenant water.  However, in this study paratization rates were high in the floodplain nest location, which could account for the expanded use of upland nest locations. They also elucidated two additional studies in Missouri and Minnesota where there were similar results.  Wood ducks generally use shallow waters or waters edge. Anderson et al. (1981), Nests in low slow moving waters of <18 inches deep.
